question: Lieutenant... izat you? What're you doing here lieutenant?
answer: This is where I belong... this is my outfit.

question: You went to hospital?
answer: It was no good... what's going on here?

question: Lt. John J. Dunbar.
Lt. John J. Dunbar.
Indian fighter, huh?
Your orders say you are to be posted on the frontier. The frontier is Indian country. I quickly deduced that you are an Indian fighter. I did not ascend to this position by being stupid.
It says here you've been decorated.
And they sent you out here to be posted?
answer: Actually sir, I'm here at my own request... I want to see the frontier.

question: You want to see the frontier?

Such a smart lad coming straight to me. Sir Knight, I am sending you on a knight's errand. You will report to Captain Cargill at the furthermost outpost of the realm... Fort Sedgewick. My personal seal will assure you safe passage through many miles of wild hostile country.
answer: I'm wondering sir, how will I be getting there?

question: You think I don't know?
answer: No sir, it's just that I don't know.

question: Hold your tongue. I'm in a generous mood and will grant your boon. You see that peasant... he calls himself Timmons... he leaves this very afternoon for your Fort Sedgewick. Ride with him if you like... he knows the way. That is all. Sir Knight... I just pissed in my pants... and nobody can do anything about it. Noooo, noooo...
Nooo, nooo...
Are you deaf fool. I said I'll have my crown this instant... this instant!
We have been gone four days now and still we have seen no signs of life. Only earth and sky. How far do you make the fort?
How far?
answer: Forty or fifty miles, maybe... what's the big hurry on Sedgewick?

question: It's going to be my post... my home.
answer: You ain't hard to please, I'll say that. Look yonder.

question: Somebody back east is sayin'... "why don't he write?" Stupid bastard.
answer: Timmons... Timmons. Timmons. Something's out there...

question: Somethin' dead.
Ain't nothin' here lieutenant. Everybody's run off... or got kilt.
What, and leave it all here?
answer: I'm staying too... we don't know what's happened.

question: There ain't nothin' here lieutenant.
So things bein' the way they are we might as well turn around and get started back.
This is my... are you crazy boy?
answer: This is my post! And these are the post's provisions. Now get your ass off that wagon and help me unload.

question: May I come in? No, no let him sit with me. Our country seems good this summer, but I have not been out to see it.
answer: Yes... it is good. The grass is rich. The game is plenty and not running away.

question: I am glad to hear it. But the buffalo are late. I always worry about the bellies of our children.
answer: I was thinking of a dance.

question: Yes, a dance is always a good idea. It would be good to have a strong sign.

There's a funny thing about signs. They are always flying in our faces. We know when they are bad or good but sometimes they are strange and there is no way to understand them. Sometimes they make people crazy but a smart man will take such a sign into himself and let it run around for two or three days. If he is still confused he will tell somebody. He might come to you or to me and tell it. A smart man always does that.
answer: I have seen such a sign.

question: Oh?
answer: I saw a man, a white man.

question: Just one?
Are you sure it was a man?
Did you speak to him?
We will council on this.
answer: He might be a god or he might be a special chief -- that's why we are thinking of having a talk with him.

question: He might be a god or he might be a special chief -- that's why we are thinking of having a talk with him.
answer: I do not care for this talk about a white man. Whatever kind of white man he is, he is not Sioux and that makes him less. We've camped here for ten days now and each day our scouts find nothing. One old bull with wolves tearing him apart, nothing more. We need meat -- not talk.

question: You are right, we need meat today and tomorrow. But we must also have meat in ten years. But the whites are coming. Our friends the Shoshone and the Kiowa, even our enemies, agree on this -- the whites are coming. More than can be counted.
answer: Kicking Bird is always looking ahead and that is good. But when I hear that more whites are coming -- more than can be counted I want to laugh. We took a hundred horses from these people, there was no honor in it. They don't ride well, they don't shoot well, they're dirty. They have no women, no children. They could not even make it through one winter in our country. And these people are said to flourish? I think they will all be dead in ten years. I think this white man is probably lost.

question: Wind In His Hair has spoken straight, his words are strong and I have heard them. It's true the whites are a poor race and it's hard to understand them. But when I see one white man alone, without fear in our country, I do not think he is lost. I think he may have medicine. I see someone who might speak for all the white people who are coming. I think this is a person with which treaties might be struck.
answer: This white man cannot cover our lodges, or string our bows, or feed our children. I will take some good men... there are many here tonight. We will ride to the soldier fort, we will shoot some arrows into this white man. If he truly has medicine he will not be hurt. If he has no medicine he will be dead.

question: If we take the horse of a white god they will make up songs about us.
They will ask us to go on raids.
answer: Who gets the white god horse?

question: What happened?
answer: I don't know. My arm doesn't work.

question: You shouldn't have fallen down... now we'll get in trouble.
My idea was only to take the horse. Otter hurt himself.
Your wounds are healing well?
You are happy here, with my family?
answer: I am glad to be here. I am missing my husband.

question: Perhaps you will marry again when the time is right.

We have word from many places that the whites are... They are coming into everyone's country. They will soon be in ours I think. This white man who lives at the old soldier fort, the one who calls himself loo ten tant... I have visited him and I believe his heart is a good one. He knows things about the whites which we do not.
answer: I am afraid of the man at the fort.

question: He is only one man.
answer: I am afraid that he will tell some whites that I am here. I am afraid that they will try to take me away.

question: Every warrior in camp would fight them if they tried. I cannot make the white man talk. Loo ten tant does not know Sioux. You have a certain medicine which no other Sioux -- man or woman -- has.
answer: It has been a long time since I made the talk.

question: I do not ask this for myself... I ask this for all our people.
I want you to try and remember the the word.
Look I'm full... I can't tell the story again. Go ahead. You want to try... put it on. Here. This is too much... I can't take this... I can't... No more...
I can't, I'm full... very full... That's my hat. My hat.
answer: That hat belongs to my friend here. You can see that he wants it now. We all know that is a soldier hat. We all know who wears it. If you want to keep it that's alright. But give something for it. Good trade.

question: Our... names?
He wants to know how we are called.
He... he... Kick...
More.
Kicking... yes... Kicking... Bird.
answer: Kicking Bird... What does he... is he a chief?

question: Hul... hal... ho-lee... holy... holy man.
I don't know.
No.
Yes... Stands. More... Wiff... With.
answer: Stands With A... Fist? Stands With A Fist. I'm John... John Dunbar.

question: John Dunbar.
answer: Yes. I try to answer all of Kicking Bird's questions but I know he is frustrated with me. He always wants to know how many more white people are coming. I tell him that it is impossible for me to say. When he persists I tell him that the white people will most likely pass through this country and nothing more. But I am speaking to him in half- truths. One day there will be too many, but I cannot bring myself to tell him that. I am sure that Stands With A Fist knows. A war party is going against the Pawnee soon and I have asked to go. I sensed that I have made a mistake in doing so but I could not bring myself to take it back. They are my friends and from what little I gather the Pawnee have been very hard on these people. I hope I have not overstepped my bounds. I'm glad to see you... please sit.

question: Kicking Bird wants to know why you want to make war on the Pawnee. They have done nothing to you.
Only Sioux warriors will go.
answer: I asked that he would think about my going.

question: He has.
answer: Then tell him this. I have been a warrior for longer than many of the young men that will go on this war party. Tell him.

question: He says that the Sioux way of being a warrior is not the white way. You are not ready.
answer: I know, I understand. But I cannot learn these ways in camp.

question: He asks that you watch over his family while he is gone. This thing he asks you... it is a great honor for you.
answer: I will be happy to watch over your family.

question: He thanks Dances With Wolves for coming.
It is the name which everyone is calling you now.
answer: Dances With Wolves... that's right. How do you say it?

question: Dances With Wolves.
I like to make the white man talk. Dances With Wolves?
Grass grows on the prairie.
Wrong. That man is a fighter.
That man is a fighter.
answer: Alright... I have it... That man...

question: Yes...
answer: Is... A... bone! A bone... right? What is the word for beautiful?

question: How did you get your name?
answer: I was not very old when I came to be with the people... I was made to work. I worked every day... very hard... there was a woman who didn't like me. She called me bad names... sometimes she beat me. One day she was calling me these bad names, her face in my face, and I hit her. I was not very big, but she fell down. She fell hard and didn't move. I stood over her with my fist and asked if any other woman wanted to call me bad names... No one bothered me after that day.

question: I would not think so. Show me where you hit her. Why are you not married?
I'm sorry. Let me help...
Some of your words are wrong... but you are learning fast. That is good. What can I tell you today?
answer: I want to know about Stands With A Fist.

question: What is your question?
answer: There is no man with her.

question: She is in mourning.
She is crying for someone.
It is not polite to speak of the dead... But I will tell you... you are new. She cries for her husband. He was killed not long ago.
People are talking about you...
They are proud of the medicine you are making with Dances With Wolves.
answer: I have hurt him and I must go talk to him.

question: You can't, he is gone.
I am in mourning.
answer: I know... Stone Calf told me.

question: No one can know... we must be careful.
Stone Calf... wait... I have guns... many far-shooting guns.
answer: No, the ride is long... the weather is bad. We can spare no men.

question: Guns would make one warrior like two.
answer: Take one man and go quickly.

question: Wait.
answer: Hear us now. A white soldier with many far-shooting guns... how would he fight the Pawnee?

question: I would hide in the village.
answer: Dances With Wolves has not finished.

question: I would let the enemy think we are asleep... let him come close. Then we would shoot together and run to fight them, drive them into the river and kill so many that they would never trouble us again.
answer: I am of the same mind as Dances With Wolves... we should kill so many that they never trouble us again.

question: How long will Stands With A Fist mourn?
I hope it will not be too long.
She has found love again.
Dances With Wolves.
When you see them together you will know.
answer: What are people saying? They're not angry?

question: No. They like the match. It makes sense. They are both white.
answer: I suppose I will be the one to say something.

question: She has been released. Kicking Bird did it.
What are you doing?
answer: Kicking Bird told me to wait.

question: You might be waiting a long time. Smiles A Lot says he saw Kicking Bird riding on the prairie... He says he was talking to himself. When a medicine man is the last to know he can take it pretty hard.
You are pretty poor my friend and a Sioux girl is not for free. I don't know if you can get married.
That's too much medicine.
answer: Do you think the buckskin is too much medicine?

question: This is a good day for me.
Stands With A Fist... if you want this man, take his hand in yours.
answer: I had never been married before. I don't know if all grooms have the same experience. But as Kicking Bird began to speak about what was expected of a Sioux husband, my mind began to swim in a way that shut out everything but her. The tiny details of her costume. The contours of her shape. The light in her eyes. The smallness of her feet. I knew that the love between us would be served.

question: Have you heard all that I have said?
Good, then take her inside... she is your wife.
It's good to be out.
We are trying for a baby.
No waiting.
answer: I was just thinking that of all the trails in this life, there is one that matters more than all the others. It is the trail of a true human being. I think you are on this trail and it is good to see.

question: I speak english...
Lieutenant John. J. Dunbar. This is my post.
answer: Why are you dressed like this?

question: What is your name?
You say you are an officer?
No.
There are no orders and there is no journal. Why are you out of uniform?
There are no hostiles.
answer: We will ascertain that for ourselves. Now if you guide us to these camps and serve as an interpreter, your conduct will be reevaluated.

question: What conduct?
answer: Your status as a traitor might improve should you choose to cooperate with the United States Army.

question: Dances With Wolves is quiet these days. Is his heart bad?
answer: Killing the soldiers at the river was a good thing. It made me free and my heart was big to see my friends coming to help me. I did not mind killing those men. I was glad to do it. But the soldiers hate me now like they hate no other. I am more than an enemy to them, I am a traitor. They will hunt for me. They will not give up. And when they find me they find you and that cannot happen.

question: Quiet!... sit down Wind In His Hair. You are hurting an old man's ears with your loud talk. Dances With Wolves? Ahh... this is a nice fire... at my age a good fire is better than anything. I wondered how your bad heart was doing and though I would come by and see for myself. This place doesn't look so bad-hearted.
But you are leaving anyway?
answer: I have talked with Stands With a Fist and we will go together.

question: Have you told this to Kicking Bird or to Wind In His Hair. You are the only white man I have ever known. I have thought about you alot. More than you know.

You have always spoken with your heart. And like all of us, you are a free man and can do anything you like. When I look across this fire, I do not see a white soldier. I see only a Sioux named Dances With Wolves. And there is nothing they hate so much as a Sioux. You are making a pipe?
This might be a pretty good pipe... how does it smoke?
answer: I don't know, I haven't tried it yet.
